event: In October 1997, in Tulsa, Oklahoma, white supremacist James Viefhaus, Jr., 28, was charged with conspiracy to willfully make bomb threat, willfully making a bomb threat, and possession of a non-registered destructive device. This was carried out through Viefhaus leaving a phone message threatening to bomb 15 U.S. cities via an Aryan Intelligence Network hotline operated by Viefhaus and his fiancé at the time, Carol E. Howe, both the founding and only members of the National Socialist Alliance of Oklahoma. Viefhaus was motivated by his right-wing beliefs as evidenced by his organization which sought for "the destruction of blacks, Jews, homosexuals, and federal law enforcement agents". Howe acted as an informant for the case and charged against her were dropped.

In 1997, in Orlando Florida, Todd Vanbiber, age 29, was charged with possessing and manufacturing explosive devices. Vanbiber, an alleged member of the neo-Nazi National Alliance and the League of the Silent Soldier, had been plotting to set off pipe bombs on major roadways in Florida to distract from a bank robbery he was planning but accidently set off the bombs early in his storage shed when checking them. His actions were motivated by his neo-Nazi ideology.

In 1999 in Elkgrove, CA, Kiles, 49, and Patterson, 42 were charged with 4 felony weapons charges. The men - members of the San Joaquin County Militia - had amassed a stache of guns, ammunition, bomb chemicals and methamphetamine ingredients with the goal to blow up storage tanks near Elk Grove that together hold about 24 million gallons of liquid. The men hoped to prompt a declaration of martial law, then civic unrest and, ultimately, a militia takeover of the federal government, court documents say.
Donald Rudolph was the head of the San Joaquin Militia in which he and other members planned to kill members of the federal government and use propane tanks to cause mass destruction.

In 2001, in Middlesboro, Kentucky, Steve Anderson, age 54, was charged with weapons charges. Anderson, a member of the Kentucky State Militia and a prolific white-nationalist pirate radio broadcaster, had shot at a police officer with an automatic weapon after being stopped for a traffic violation and spent a number of months on the run, eventually being caught in the mountains. His actions were motivated by his rightist: identity-focused belief system.

William Krar and his common-law wife Judith Bruey were found in possession of illegally owned weapons, including a cyanide bomb. He also had connections to New Jersey militia, which was thought to be his supplier of weapons.

Defendants charged in the 'STONE' group were members of the group Hutaree. According to the indictment, Hutaree members view local, state, and federal law enforcement as the “brotherhood”, their enemy, and have been preparing to engage them in armed conflict. The indictment also alleges that the Hutaree planned to kill an unidentified member of local law enforcement and then attack the law enforcement officers who would gather in Michigan for the funeral. According to the plan, the Hutaree would attack law enforcement vehicles during the funeral procession with improvised explosive devices with explosively formed projectiles, which, according to the indictment, constitute weapons of mass destruction. Subsequently, and in furtherance of this plan, David Brian Stone, the Hutaree’s leader, obtained information about such devices over the Internet and e-mailed diagrams of such devices to a person he believed capable of manufacturing the devices. Additionally all nine defndants were charged with carrying or possessing a firearm during a crime of violence on at least one occasion. All of the defendants pleaded not guilty and were aquitted with the exception of David Brian Stone Sr., Joshua John Clough, and Joshua Matthew Stone who pleaded not guilty and were found guilty on some charges and sentenced to time served of 28 months.

In 2013, agents with the FBI arrested militia member Buford Braden “Bucky” Rogers, of Montevideo, Minnesota, after discovering two Molotov cocktails, two “black powder and nail devices,” a pipe bomb, and a semi‐automatic rifle at his home. Rogers was a convicted felon prohibited from possessing firearms. An FBI affidavit asserted that Rogers regularly talked of plans to use his militia group, a tiny group called the Black Snake Militia, to cut off communications to the City of Montevideo, raid the National Guard Armory, and bomb the Montevideo Police Department. Rogers pleaded guilty to being a felon in possession of a firearm and possessing an unregistered destructive device and received a 40‐ month prison sentence.

Woodring, an anti-government extremist, commits three sabotage attacks over several weeks on the local power grid. One attack on a high-voltage station in Scott, Arkansas, causes $4 million in damage. He pleads guilty to using fire to commit a felony, among other charges.

Terry Eugene Peace, Brian Edward Cannon and Cory Robert Williamson, attempted to obtain thermite and pipe bombs in order to launch terrorist attacks against the federal government. Based on online comments they made, the trio seem to have hoped to spark a government overreaction that would cause the militia movement to rise up. Cannon, Peace and Williamson targeted the infrastructure supporting their federal agency targets because they believed this would reduce the amount of unnecessary casualties and make it difficult for the government to respond to their attack. When going to pick up the pipe bombs the men were intercepted by police due to work with an informant. All defendants pleaded guilty and were sentenced to 144 months in prison.

On March 30, 2016, in Tyngsborough/Tyngsboro, Massachusetts, 61 year old Danny M. Kelly started a fire, placed incendiary devices on utility lines, and left a manifesto railing against government corruption near the scene. Prior to the attack, Kelly had a history of civil and criminal disputes with local government, including an eminent domain case regarding the use of his property for a public utilities project.
target: Federal site: non-U.S. embassy or consulate

event: On September 25, 2016, Stephen Plato McRae fired shots at the Buckskin Electrical Substation, causing the substation to overheat and fail. In the plea agreement for this charge, McRae admitted to damaging several other facilities and authorities agreed not to charge him for those offenses. The locations of the other damages are: Libson Valley Substation in San Juan County on April 1, 2015; Quinn River Substation in Humboldt County, Nevada on August 31, 2016; and Baker Substation in White Pine County, Nevada, on September 14, 2016. According to the state, he told a confidential informant he was trying to "destroy industrial capitalism" and "do millions of dollars of damage to the fossil fuel industry.”

(Army National Guard) Brandon Russell is a dangerous Neo-Nazi leader who was found to have lethal bomb-making materials in his Florida apartment after his roommate shot two of their other roommates. Russell is a dual citizen with the US and the Bahamas and an active duty member of the Florida National Guard. Russell and his roommate Devon Arthurs (the shooter) were co-founders of the Atomwaffen Division. Russell was not found to be connected to the murder of his roommates. The bomb-making materials were found amongst other neo-Nazi propaganda, including a framed picture of Timothy McVeigh and the Turner Diaries. Russell's attorney argues that Russell has mental deficiencies (ADHD and Autism) and that the bomb-makng materials were not going to be used. One of Russell's murdered roommates, Andrew Oneschuk, was also a member of AWD and had ties to the Azov Battalion in Ukraine.

(marine) Lance Cpl. Vasillios G. Pistolis, a Marine alleged to have connections to a violent neo-Nazi organization, was booted from the Corps on July 11, according to Maj. Brian Block, a Marine spokesman. In June, Pistolis was sentenced before a military court to 28 days confinement, reduction in rank to E-1 and forfeiture of two-thirds pay for one month following an explosive report exposing the Marine’s connection to the neo-Nazi group Atomwaffen Division and his violent participation at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, in August 2017.

On December 22, 2017, in Reston, VA, Nicholas Giampa, 17, was charged with two counts of murder. This was carried out by Giampa sneaking into his girlfriends home, when her parents discovered him, he drew a handgun and shot both parents before unsuccessfully attempting suicide by shooting himself. As @doctorpepper35, Giampa tweeted about his hatred of transgender people and his admiration for Adolf Hitler. He tweeted about using Jews as target practice. Online, Giampa had repeatedly interacted with white supremacist groups, in particular the Atomwaffen Division. The Frickers had staged an intervention for their daughter to keep her from dating an "outspoken neo-Nazi" and had even reported Giampa's hate speech to the special education high school the two attended. Initially, Giampa was ruled incompetent to stand trial due to brain damage from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. After spending months in a mental hospital, Giampa was deemed competent to stand trial. Giampa's sentencing is coded as data not available because his records are not available through Fairfax County Circuit Court, and his name has not appeared in the news since 2019.

James Alex Fields Jr. of Ohio was charged with second-degree murder in Charlottesville, Va., after the authorities said he drove a car into a crowd, leaving a 32-year-old woman dead and injuring at least 19 other people who were protesting a rally staged by white nationalists.
Four members of California based White supremacist group traveled to incite a riot at 2017 Charlottesville, Virginia 'Unite the Right' protest

On May 3, 2019, Benjamin Drake Daley, 26, pleaded guilty in Charlottesville to one count of conspiracy to riot in connection with the August 2017 “Unite the Right '' rally in Virginia and other political rallies in California, alongside Benjamin Drake Daley. They were both members of the white supremacist organization, Rise Above Movement (RAM). Daley has been identified as one of the founders of RAM, and was chiefly responsible for organizing their presence at Unite the Right. They admitted to intentionally provoking and engaging in violent confrontations; RAM even held combat training meetings prior to the rallies.

On May 3, 2019, Michael Paul Miselis, 30, pleaded guilty in Charlottesville to one count of conspiracy to riot in connection with the August 2017 “Unite the Right '' rally in Virginia and other political rallies in California, alongside Benjamin Drake Daley. They were both members of the white supremacist organization, Rise Above Movement (RAM). They admitted to intentionally provoking and engaging in violent confrontations; RAM even held combat training meetings prior to the rallies.

Four members of a white supremacy organization have been indicted on riot charges for participating in attacks at several politcal rallies in 2017. Rundo is the founder of the "Rise Above Movement" and was arrested after he fled the country to Mexico. Members of RAM also reportedly met with Olena Semanyaka, the leader of the Ukrainian National Corps, the civilian arm of the Azov Battalion.

Woodward, 21, was ordered to stand trial on murder and hate crime charges after prosecutors linked him to the stabbing of Blaze Bernstein through DNA evidence. The prosecutors demonstrated that Woodward had troves of homophobic and neo-Nazi material on his mobile phone, as well as an active affiliation to Atomwaffen Division. Woodward was reportedly sexually confused and had a habit of "pranking" gay men on dating apps. Woodward met up with Bernstein and, when Bernstein tried to kiss him, stabbed him repeatedly in the neck. Because of the attack on Bernstein due to his sexuality, Woodward will receive a hate crime enhancement in sentencing.

On November 15th, 2018, Jeffrey Raphiel Clark Jr., 30, was indicted for Unlawful Possession of Firearms by Person Who is Unlawful User of any Controlled Substance and Possession of a Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device under DC code. Jeffrey and his brother, Edward "Teddy" Clark, were active on the social media site Gab, where they were active in Alt-Right forums and in the white nationalist movement, attended the "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, and were identiified as holding a Vanguard America flag in one of their images. They were both "friends" with Robert Bowers, the perpetrator of the Tree-of-Life Synagogue attack on October 27th, 2018. On the same day of the attack, Edward Clark took his own life, resulting in an escalation of Jeffrey's radicalized views. Two witnesses reported Jeffrey to the FBI due to his extreme agitation, worried he was a threat to himself and others. The witnesses assisted agents in recovering firearms and AR-15-modifying parts and conversion kits, and informed them of Jeffrey's drug use. In court, Jeffrey plead guilty to the drug charge but not the weapon charge, and was sentenced to time served (10 months) and 36 months of supervised release.

At about 8 p.m. on Oct. 12, 2018, several members of the Proud Boys were leaving an event at the Metropolitan Republican Club while members of antifa protested outside, according to prosecutors. As they exited the event, Hare, Kinsman and others from their group taunted members of antifa and made verbal and nonverbal threats, prosecutors said. Antifa protesters later intercepted Hare, Kinsman, and at least eight other Proud Boys, where the defendants charged at them and a dispute ensued, according to prosecutors. Hare, Kinsman and others then assaulted four antifa members, striking them with their hands, fists, feet, elbows and boots until NYPD officers arrived, prosecutors said.

On May 2, 2019, Benjamin Bogard, 20 of Texas, pled guilty to possession of obscene visual representations of the sexual abuse of children. He had a plan to carry out mass violence and hate crimes. Times Union reports, Bogard "belong[s] to a neo-Nazi group, Atomwaffen Division, because a person in the posts was saluting Adolf Hitler. The man was wearing a mask of a skull over part of his face, a signature sign of the group, officials said." He was collecting firearms and explosive for an attack.

event: In 2019, in Boston, Massachusetts, Christopher Hood, age 20, and Tyler Larson, age 18, were charged with carrying dangerous weapons. Matthew Wolf, age 26 was charged with assault and battery upon a police officer. The three men, all members of Patriot Front, allegedly dressed in face masks and hoods while hanging white nationalist propaganda in East Boston. Larson was carrying brass knuckles and Hood was carrying a spring loaded 5-inch knife. Wolf slapped a police officer's hand when the officer reached for Wolf's identification. Their actions were motivated by their white nationalist ideology.

Jason Van Dyke, a white police officer affiliated with the Proud Boys, fatally shot black 17 year old Laquan McDonald 16 times in October of 2014. Bodycam footage showed that McDonald was backing away as he was shot. Van Dyke was sentenced to six years in prison. The punishment was handed down just a day after three other Chicago police officers were acquitted after being accused of helping cover up what happened. Van Dyke served three years and four months of his sentence before he was released early.

(coast guard) In 2019, in Maryland, a 49-year-old Coast Guard lieutenant charged with stockpiling weapons and drugs is being described as a "domestic terrorist" who was planning "to murder innocent civilians on a scale rarely seen in this country," according to court documents filed in U.S. District Court in Maryland on Tuesday. Court documents say Hasson espoused extremist and white supremacist views and allege that he relied on the manifesto of Anders Breivik, a Norwegian who was convicted in 2011 of two terror attacks that killed 77 people. As detailed in court documents, to prepare himself to take action, in addition to the firearms and silencers referenced above, Hasson purchased holsters, knives, magazines, ammunition, handguards, camping supplies, Meals-Ready-to-Eat, steel body armor plates, plate carriers, tactical vests and pouches, firearm repair kits, and smoke grenades.

Proud Boys member Donovan Flippo was arrested 3/12/2019 with Tiny Toese and charged with third-degree assault and fourth-degree assault in connection to the same alleged assault that occurred on June 8, 2018 in a secret indictment. Both men were arrested on June 30, 2018 at a rally hosted by the group Patriot Prayer, which continually clashes with anti-fascist members on the streets of downtown Portland, along with Luiz E. Marquez, and Matthew R. Braddock.. Flippo’s indictment mentions Toese, but at the time of Flippo’s arrest, Toese was not yet in custody. Donovon Flippo was charged with third-degree assault (a class C felony) and fourth-degree assault. Flippo pleaded guilty to fourth-degree assault, a misdemeanor. On 7/17/2019 Donavan was sentenced to two years of probation and ordered him not to participate in any mass protests in Multnomah County. He must complete 40 hours of community service within six months and have no contact with the victim in the case. He also was sentenced to eight days in jail, which he already served after his March arrest in Clark County. After his arrest, Flippo was transferred to Multnomah County and posted bail. On 10/24/2019 he was sentenced to 10 days in jail for probation violation.

According to police reports, Flippo and Toese were driving around Portland in a truck bearing a flag emblazoned with Donald Trump’s face. A man on the street, Timothy Ledwith, recognized Toese and taunted him about losing his sandals in a previous fight with left-wing anti-fascist activists, Willamette Week reported. In response, Toese and Flippo got out of the car and pursued Ledwith. Toese, who was wearing an “Antifa Removal Service” shirt during the incident, later told police that he punched Ledwith in the face. Pictures of Ledwith taken after the attack show him with a bloody nose and lip.

On July 13th, 2021, Corbin Kauffman, 31, was sentenced 18 months' imprisonment for posting threatening social media content on March 13th, 2019. The post in question featured Kauffman aiming an AR-15 rifle at a congregation of praying Jewish men. Kauffman had previously posted images of himself under various aliases threatening other religious and racial groups as well.

In 2019, in New Braunfels, Texas, Benjamin Bogard, 20, was convicted of child pornography charges when graphic images were found on his cell phone during a counterterrorism investigation into his online postings. The FBI received a tip about Bogard in early November 2018, after someone called a police hotline to report his social-media posts “involving domestic terroristic threats that included threats of mass violence,” specifically related to looking for minorities, Mexicans, and women, "anything that is shit." Additionally, Bogard indicated allegiance to Atomwaffen. He was sentenced to six years and eight months in federal prison for child pornography after his phone was searched from the original tip.

On May 28, 2019, in San Bernadino, CA, Skyler Gene Butts, 34, was charged with Vandalism and Attempted Malicious Mischief. This wad carried out when Butts tagged various areas in Colorado River Station areas on federal land. He utilized graffiti to tag various areas with Flat Earth Society and the Rise Above Movement symbols, which is a Neo-Nazi White Supremacist movement.

In 2019, in Fairfax, Virginia, Brian Patrick Baynes, age unknown, was charged with violating 18:922(g)(3) Illegal possession of a firearm by a controlled substance abuser (in or affecting interstate commerce). Baynes, a member of the neo-Nazi group Atomwaffen Division, had purchased a long rifle and revolver despite being a user of narcotics. A part of Baynes sentencing was that he "shall not possess view, access, or otherwise use material that reflects extremist or terroristic views or is deemed to be inappropriate by the U.S. Probation and Pretrial Services Office."

In August of 2019 the FBI arrested twenty-three year old security guard Conor Climo on suspicion of possessing parts to make a bomb. According to the FBI, Climo wanted to contribute "his knowledge of constructing explosive devices toward a 'righteous' cause” and originally joined the Baltic branch of the Atomwaffen Division. Columbia, South Carolina, 12 June 2020: Kevin Alexander Ackley, 22, was charged with inciting a riot (felony) and disturbing the peace (misdemeanor) after throwing a water bottle at law enforcement officers during a Black Lives Matter protest over the weekend of 29 May 2020. Ackley, an emergency medical services worker, is allegedly part of the extremist group Boogaloo Bois. “It’s disgusting that a man who is supposed to be protecting the lives of citizens and law enforcement officers alike would participate in a riot that injured people,” Lexington County Sheriff Leon Lott said in a prepared statement. “He is now where he needs to be — in jail. And he’ll be held accountable for what he’s done.”

On April 15, 2019, James Christopher Benvie, 45, of Albany, MN, he stopped six women and children from El Salvador at the "camp" at the Southwest border in Doña Ana County, New Mexico. He had misrepresented himself as a Border Patrol agent and interrogated immigrants before turning them over to actual Border Patrol agents. On April 17, 2019, Benvie stopped 4 adults and 3 children who he believed were entering the United States illegally. He is a part of the United Constitutional Patriots (UCP), established in early 2019, whom of which camp along a 52-mile stretch of the U.S.-Mexico border along the eastern edge of New Mexico, near El Pas, Texas.

Justen Michael Watkins, 25, of Bad Axe, Michigan, was arrested in a joint opperation raid between the Michigan State Police and F.B.I.. Watkins is being charged with three non-federal felony counts in the state of Michigan (Washtenaw County 14A District Court): Unlawful Post (MCL 750.411s), Gang Membership (750.411u), and Computers-use to Commit a Crime (750.145d). Upcoming hearing on 12/17/2020 (scheduled for probable cause conference). Watkins is the self-proclaimed leader of violent, national white supremacist group The Base and caught the FBI's attention in Dec. 2019 after posing for and posting photos of himself on a family's house in Dexter, MI — Watkins thought the house to belong to Daniel Harper of the Antifa podcast "I Don't Speak German", but he had the wrong house. The photos were uploaded to The Base’s channel on the social media platform Telegram.

Alfred Charles Gorman, 35, of Taylor, Michigan, was arrested in a joint opperation raid between the Michigan State Police and F.B.I.. Gorman is being charged with three non-federal felony counts in the state of Michigan (Washtenaw County 14A District Court): Unlawful Post (MCL 750.411s), Gang Membership (750.411u), and Computers-use to Commit a Crime (750.145d). Upcoming hearing on 12/17/2020 (scheduled for probable cause conference). The photos were uploaded to The Base’s channel on the social media platform Telegram by Gorman and Watkins.

"A federal criminal complaint filed...[which] charges 21–year-old Cameron Emerson Casey Rankin with one count of being a prohibited person in possession of a firearm as a result of previously being committed to a mental institution. FBI agents arrested Rankin...and recovered a black semi-automatic rifle during the execution of a search warrant at his residence...According to the criminal complaint, Rankin was in unlawful possession of a firearm, with the capability and means to affect violence in furtherance of his beliefs and has expressed a desire to overthrow the government, specifically, the “three letter agencies” such as ATF, FBI and IRS...Rankin attempted to purchase two long guns from a San Antonio retail outlet on March 23, 2018, but was denied the firearms transactions under the “Prohibited Category” for previously being committed to a mental institution. After being warned by agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) that he was a prohibited person, Rankin posted pictures of himself with a firearm on social media. On May 30, 2020, Rankin and others, carrying long guns and pistols, appeared at the Alamo in downtown San Antonio to attend a protest in reaction to the death of George Floyd. The next day, Rankin posted on his Facebook account photos of himself and others carrying a firearm at the protest as well as comments about his disdain for police including, “…hope they burn the precinct down” and “I’m BOOGALOO we hate police.”...on August 4, 2020, Rankin posted a “selfie” photo on his Facebook timeline showing him holding a black, semi-automatic rifle in a vertical position against his shoulder with his finger on the trigger. Rankin posted other photos which included a quote, stating, “Diligently Plotting to Take Over the World in order to Leave You Alone”. On August 11, 2020, Rankin arrived at the airport in Manchester, New Hampshire. He flew out of San Antonio International Airport the previous day. Rankin checked a semiautomatic handgun in his luggage while at the ticket counter, but missed a connecting flight in Philadelphia, PA. Upon his arrival in Manchester, Rankin was met inside the terminal by ATF agents who served Rankin written notice that he is prohibited from possessing firearms. The agents also provided him with copies of his mental health records. Agents seized the handgun and ammunition from inside Rankin’s luggage. Rankin threw the notice letter and mental health records in the trash receptacle before leaving the airport terminal. (DOJ press release)"

event: "On April 7, 2022, Ivan Harrison Hunter, a 28-year-old resident of Boerne, Texas, was sentenced in the District of Minnesota to 52 months incarceration after pleading guilty to one count of rioting. Hunter, an adherent of the Boogaloo movement, traveled from Texas to Minnesota in May 2020 and met up with other Boogaloo movement members who had mobilized to Minneapolis following the murder of George Floyd. On May 28, 2020, during a period of rioting near the Third Precinct Building of the Minneapolis Police Department, Hunter fired 13 rounds from an AK-47 assault rifle into the entryway of the building. Following this criminal conduct, Hunter returned to Texas and continued to communicate with his fellow Boogaloo movement members, including Steven Carrillo – who shot two Protective Services officers at the Ronald V. Dellums Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse in Oakland, California on the same day as Hunter’s actions in Minneapolis." (George Washington University, Program on Extremism)

On 11/8/2020 to 10/30/2020, TJWatson committed conspiracy in West Virginia to possess and transfer machineguns/conversion devices for AR15s, without paying an occupational tax, conspiracy against the U.S. Government and selling machine gun conversion devices to extremists. It is reported he sold hundeds of these conversion devices to boogaloo adherents.

On May 12th, 2020, Joseph Miner and Daniel Jou met with an undercover agent at the Queens Hotel and purchased from him weapons, many with obliterated serial numbers. Jou purchased a Glock 19 handgun with an obliterated serial number and a fully automatic assault rifle with a silencer attachment and high capacity magazine. Jou pleaded guilty to Unlawful Possession of a Firearm and was sentenced to 30 months in prison, as well as two years supervised release.

On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. Fox was sentenced to 192 months in prison, and Croft was sentenced to 235 months in prison.

On January 4, 2021, Henry Tarrio was arrested for burning a Black Lives Matter flag outside of a Black church in December. Following his arrest, police found two high-capacity firearms magazines from his bookbag. Tarrio claimed that he was selling the magazines, and they were returned to him when he mailed them so he had planned on delivering them to his customer while he was in Washington, D.C. The magazines depicted Proud Boys logos and images. Tarrio is the national chairman of the Proud Boys according to the affidavit.
Joshua Pruitt, 39, was arrested for a curfew violation after the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests. He has two entries in this datasheet as he was charged both federally and non federally

Dayton Charles Sauke, 22, of Owatonna, MN pleaded guilty to one count of possession of an unregistered firearm, a 'sawed off' shotgun. On January 12, 2021, the defendant posted numerous threats online via Snapchat directing violence at law enforcement and politicians. He also agreed to sell a privately made firearm to an undercover ATF agent via Snapchat

In 2021, in Queens, New York, Eduard Florea, 40, was arrested and charged with Transmission of threats to injure and Felon in possession of ammunition. Florea used Parler to make general threats to carry out violence as well as specific threats toward the Georgia democratic senator Warnock. When arrested, officers discovered ammunition and 75 military-style combat knives. Florea has a previous illegal weapons charge.As set forth in greater detail below, EDUARD FLOREA, who has previously been convicted of a firearms-related felony, posted threatening statements online on and around January 6, 2021, including statements about killing a United States Senator-elect and about intending to travel to Washington, D.C. as part of a group armed with firearms that was ready to engage in violence (although evidence gathered in this investigation to date indicates that EDUARD FLOREA did not ultimately travel to Washington, D.C. on that date). A search of FLOREA’s residence revealed that he was in possession of more than a thousand rounds of ammunition, including ammunition manufactured outside of the State of New York.

Bryan Betancur, A.K.A. Bryan Clooney, A.K.A. Maximo Clooney, A.K.A. Bryan Betancourt, 23, of MD, was arrested in connection to the U.S. Capitol insurrection. Betancur was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Betancur has professed allignment with several white supremacist groups, including Patriot Front and Proud Boys, and has a history of declaring violent intentions. Betancur's probtion officer reported his attendance to the Capital insurrection, after using GPS to determine his location at the Capitol after claimed he was handing out Bibles. Betancur pled guilty to Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds and was sentenced to 4 months incarceration, 12 months’ supervised release, and $500 restitution.

Josiah Benjamin Colt, 34, of Meridian, Idaho, is charged federally with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. "[Colt] was allowed out of jail ahead of his trial as long as he abided by requirements including location monitoring, not possessing any guns or other weapons, and staying at least 1,000 feet away from both the Idaho Statehouse and the James A. McClure Federal Building, a judge ruled...Colt turned himself in to the FBI's Joint Terrorism Task Force at the Ada County Jail...FBI Special Agent Matthew J. Gano wrote in an affidavit that photos of Colt taken inside the Capitol Building and his own statements on social media prove he participated in the attempted insurrection, which was aimed at stopping lawmakers from certifying Joe Biden as the next president of the United States...The FBI agent noted that Colt also admitted to participating in the riot in a statement given to CBS News, in which he says he got "caught up in the moment" and was sorry for what he had done. (KTVB 7 news)"

Subleski was charged in a criminal complaint with a violation of 18 United States Code, Section 2101, for using a facility of interstate commerce to incite a riot and committing an act of violence in furtherance of a riot. The complaint against Subleski alleges that he was a member of the militia known as the United Pharaoh's Guard (UPG) who define themselves as Boogaloo Bois. “Boogaloo” is a term referencing a violent uprising or impending civil war. The complaint further alleges that on January 6, 2021, contemporaneous with the Capitol riots, Subleski incited a riot in downtown Louisville, Kentucky, through the use of social media and other electronic communications, and while inciting individuals to riot, he communicated through social media that it was “Time to storm LMPD.” On his Facebook page, Subleski wrote that "once R.O.E. (Rules of Engagement) get lifted ISSA BE A WATERFALL of tyrant and patriot (B)lood alike."

Turner, 35, of , IN, is charged in with communicating an interstate threat. On December 25th, 2020, Turner, while participating in a protest caravan driving through St. Matthews, confronted St. Matthews Police Officers following a traffic stop of the caravan and that during the confrontation Turner was openly carrying an AR-pistol and an additional hand gun. Following the arrest, Turner made a number of Twitter and Facebook posts threatening police officers.

February, 2021, in DC, Proud Boy members Ryan Keith Ashlock, 21, William Norman Chrestman, 47, siblings Felicia Konold, 26 and Cory Konold, 25, Louis Enrique Colon, 44, and Christopher Charles Kuehne, 47, all Kansas Chapter Proud Boys member, have been indicted together and charged with Conspiracy; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and aiding and abetting; Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder and aiding and abetting; Threatening a Federal officer; Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon; Entering and reamining in a restricted building or grounds and carrying a deadly or dangerous weapon. In addition, Chrestman has also been charged with Threatening a Federal Officer. Numerous photos depict the group participating in the march with the Proud Boys on Constitution Ave. as well as interacting with other known Proud Boys members just before the Capitol was breached. Kuehne is a retired Marine Corps officer after 22 years of service. Chrestman is a veteran of the US army. The Konold siblings are from Arizona.

Christian Alexander Secor, 22 of California, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was sentenced to 42 months of incarceration. On January 6, Secor entered the Capitol through the Senate doors, entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, and sat in Vice President Mike Pence's chair on the Senate Floor. He was also charged with assaulting police officers within the Capitol, but this charge and others were later dropped. He made  prior comments about civil war and wrote on his Twitter account that "We're legit in the Turner Diaries timeline." He was a UCLA student at the time of the riot and wore a red Make America Great Again hat and carried an America First flag. 

"The FBI said Secor is a self-identified Groyper, a network of "alt right figures who are vocal supporters of white supremacist and 'America First' podcaster Nick Fuentes. The FBI stated a tipster reported Secor founded the campus organization "America First Bruins" and is a member of Bruins Republicans. The FBI stated Secor can be seen in a group of rioters pushing their way into the building. Court documents state a tipster told the FBI that Secor moved back in with his mother after the riot, got rid of his phone and car and bragged that he would not be caught for his involvement." (USA Today)

On October 2, 2019, FBI attempted to arrest Eric Allport in Madison Heights, Michigan. Allport was shot and killed after opening fire and wounding one FBI agent. Danny Jo Thompson ll was arrested later that day for supplying Allport with a machine gun that was in Allports vehicle at the time of his arrest. Allport was killed before he reached his vehicle. Thompson and Allport were members of the Bogoloo movement and shared strong anti-police attitudes. Text messages proved that Thompson was aware that Allport was a convicted felon and knew that Allport was planning to use the acquired machine gun to kill law enforcement.

On April 8th, 2021, Jaap Willem Lijbers, a 27 year old Dutch national living in the United States on an expired I-94 Visa, pled guilty to a federal criminal complaint charging him with illegally possessing a firearm while being unlawfully present in the country. Lijbers often communicated and coordinated with the Bugaloo Bois, and found that Lijbers encouraged other members to engage in political rallies and violence inlcuding the Capital protests.

Andrew Ryan Bennett, a Columbia, Maryland Proud Boy, "livestreamed from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. In the four videos Bennett broadcast to Facebook, he wears a baseball hat adorned with the “Proud Boys” motto. In one of the videos, Bennett says, “ if you can hear me, share my stream in Discord for me,” seemingly referring to the messaging platform that’s been used by the alt-right. At one point, he chanted “break it down!” with a crowd—referring to a door located in the Speaker’s Lobby that was barricaded by police. Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt, one of the four pro-Trump protesters who died on Jan. 6, was fatally shot by a police officer while attempting to break into the Speaker’s Lobby...Bennett shared conspiracy theories online prior to the insurrection. On Jan. 4, Bennett posted a conspiracy-laden message, including his belief that President Joe Biden stole the election and Hunter Biden’s laptop....On Jan. 11, Bennett admitted to federal agents that he went to D.C. and “that he knew it was wrong” to storm the Capitol. (Daily Beast)"

Paul Miller, 32, of Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, a influential and racist content creator on the messaging platform Telegram, was arrested and indicted in March on charges of illegally acquiring and possessing weapons suppossedly as he planned for "the coming race war"

On April 5th, 2021, Michael Paul Dahlager, 26-year-old self-proclaimed "Boogaloo Boi", received a criminal complaint against him for unlawfully possessing a machine gun. Dahlager later pleaded guilty in July of 2021 of possessing two devices, auto sears, which convert semi-automatic weapons into machine guns under law. This case is the result of an investigation conducted by the FBI’s Joint Terrorism Task Force, with assistance from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF).

Elliot Bishai, Grayson Sherrill, and Elias Irizarry, attended the Capitol protests and entered the Capitol Building. Several witnesses identified Bishai and Irizarry in wanted posters published by the FBI, one of which made the identification due to the familiarity of being in the same Civil Air Patrol Unit, an official civilian auxiliary of the US Air Force.Irizarry is a current freshman and cadet at The Citadel. Bishae and Irizarry were charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, knowingly engaging in disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and violent entry and sisorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.

Christopher Worrell, 49, of FL, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; Civil Disorder; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; for his participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Worrell is a member of Proud Boys. Worrell was seen on camera spraying pepper spray gel into the crowd at the riot. Worrell has pled not guilty. This case is currently still pending.

The incident took place during a weekend of paramilitary training in Silver Creek, GA. Mathews, Lemley, and Bilbrough's cases were transferred via nolle prosequi to the federal courts.

Greene, 33, of Syracuse, NY, and William Joseph Pepe, 31, of Beacon, NY were charged with Conspiracy, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding Abetting, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting for their participation in the January 6th Capitol raid. Both Green and Pepe are memebers of Proud Boys and communicated with other Proud Boys memebrs prior to and during the Capitol raid. Additionally, Pepe posted a video of his presence inside the Capitol building, and Greene communicated via encrypted messaging channels confirming his participation. Greene initally pleaded not guilty, but later pleaded guilty per a plea bargain. The case is currently pending. [Note: Greene and Pepe were initially charged with Dominic Pezzola (A.K.A. Spazz, Spaz, Spazzo, Spazzolini; Case ID: 06062022_DP_4PROUDBOYS6), but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment in new case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in a supersceding indictment 6/6/2022, having been added to the 4PROUDBOYS group case.)

Jon Ryan Schaffer, 53, from Columbus, Indiana was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot where Schaffer sprayed "bear spray" at Capitol officers. Schaffer is a member of the Oath Keepers and has long held far-right opinions. Schaffer is also the founder of the heavy metal band "Iced Earth". Schaffer was the first person to enter a guilty plea in the Capitol riot investigation, and agreed to cooperate against others in the case.

On April 28, 2021, in Brockton, Massachusetts, Michael Robert Moura, 27, was charged as a felon in possession of a firearm, a felony offense. This was carried out via messaging to purchase illegal firearms, which he recieved stating he wanted to stockpile without being on any lists as he was worried about the administration.

On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. Fox was sentenced to 192 months in prison, and Croft was sentenced to 235 months in prison.

Marc Anthony Bru, 40, of Vancouver, WA, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; for his role in the January 6th protest. Bru was charged via anonymous tipster and videos posted to Bru's Facebook account. Bru is also a member of the Proud Boys and was seen on footage doing the "okay" sign with his hand. The sentencing information for this case is still pending.

Jessie Alexander Rush, the founder, "commanding officer," and "major" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. Rush and his codefendants were charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings for conspiring to destroy communication records relating to the murder. The Facebook group’s description stated, “they say the west won’t boog,” a reference to the “boogaloo” movement. The indictment alleged that a member of the Grizzly Scouts exchanged messages on the WhatsApp group with other Grizzly Scouts, in which that member allegedly told the group that he was preparing to engage in a shoot-out with law enforcement. Rush immediately instructed the Grizzly Scout member on the WhatsApp group to delete evidence on his phone. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The indictment also alleges that less than an hour after the shooting in Ben Lomond, Blancas deleted files related to the Grizzly Scouts from a Dropbox account. Further, within hours of the shooting, members of the Grizzly Scouts, including Rush, Blancas, Ybarra, and Miksch allegedly began to reconnect on an alternative communications application. Moreover, the indictment alleges that the four defendants each deleted records of the WhatsApp group communications from their phones, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement. Rush pleaded guilty to Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings and was sentenced to 6 months in prison.

Robert Jesus Blancas, the "1st Lieutenant" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. The Grizzly Scouts are a militia group associated with the "boogaloo" movement. The indictment alleged that a member of the Grizzly Scouts exchanged messages on the WhatsApp group with other Grizzly Scouts, in which that member allegedly told the group that he was preparing to engage in a shoot-out with law enforcement. When a member admitted to killing a federal officer, Blancas deleted 20 files from their Dropbox account, including that discussing the group's rank structure, a non-disclosure agreement requiring members of the Grizzly Scouts to maintain the confidentiality of the group’s materials, a liability release waiver, descriptions of Grizzly Scouts uniforms, and a scorecard to assess members of the Grizzly Scouts with respect to combat, firearms, medical, and other training. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The members then reconnected on alternative messaging servers where members repeatedly confirmed that they had destroyed evidence relating to the Grizzly Scouts, of which Carrillo was a member. Blancas was charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings, Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings, and Obstruction of Official Proceedings. Blancas pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 126 months in prison.

On June 1, 2021, Boogaloo Boys affiliate Tyler Joseph Light pleaded guilty to being a prohibited person in possession of a firearm after guns were found by law officers on seperate instances in November and December of 2020. Light was prohibited from possessing firearms due to a protective order obtained by his ex-wife, after recordings revealed threats towards law officials, Hispanics, and his ex-wife. His sentencing is set for August 31, 2021.

On June 6, 2021, in Fort Worth, Texas, Seth Aaron Pendley, 28, was charged with Malicious Attempt to Destroy with an Explosive a Building Used in Interstate Commerce. Pendley used the 'Signal' app to create his plans and on April 8, 2021, met an undercover FBI agent to recieve explosives for his plan. Pendley had a goal to attack "prominent tech company's data centers in an attempt to “kill of about 70% of the internet.”"

"Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6 rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and "Veterans for Trump." NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR)

"Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21." Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators." (NPR)

Paul James Kryscuk, 35, Liam Collins, 21, Jordan Duncan, 26, Justin Wade Hermanson, 21, and Joseph Maurino, 22, conspired to manufacture, transport, and sell hard to obtain firearms and firearm parts in a manner that would hide these purchases from the federal government. Collins and Kryscuk were members of and made multiple posts on the “Iron March” forum, a gathering point for young neo-Nazis to organize and recruit for extremist organizations, until the forum was closed in late 2017. Collins and Duncan are former Marines assigned previously to Camp Lejeune in Jacksonville, NC. The defendants are also charged with conspiracy to damage the property of an energy facility in the US.

Kevin A. Tuck, 51, has been charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Tuck, a member of the Proud Boys and former officer for the Windermere Police Department, posted a Youtube video after his arrest in which he called for conservatives to “rise up,” raging against Republicans and what he considers “alternative lifestyles.” “The Republican Party is weak,” Kevin Tuck said. “We need to rise up and be conservative again. Do you remember what conservative means, Republicans? Hear me out: We are embracing the homosexual lifestyle as if this is normal.” Tuck has pleaded non guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.

Arthur Jackman, 30, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Jackman, who at one point reportedly served as vice president of the Central Florida Proud Boys, was seen in news footage taking a selfie inside the Senate chamber, and texted a selfie to a childhood friend who messaged him to ask if he was involved in the riot. The accompanying text from Jackman read, “We stormed and took over,” according to a screenshot in the report. Jackman allegedly also stole an American flag and a flagpole of less than $1,000 in value. The defendant has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.

Paul Rae, 38, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Rae, who a prosecutor described as an "associate" to the Proud Boys, allegedly entered the Capitol building seconds after another Proud Boys member smashed a window. Rae has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance while he awaits sentencing. Rae has since been charged with a BUI, boating under the influence while back in Florida, this charge has been noted that it could have a bearing on his pending federal case and release status connected with the Capitol charges.

Edward George Jr., 33, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. George, a member of the Proud Boys, allegedly assaulted a law enforcement officer and stole an American flag and flagpole. He is currently released on personal recognizance.

Nathaniel Tuck, 29, has been arrested and faces several charges following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Tuck, a member of the Proud Boys and former officer with the Apopka Police Department, allegedly joined the group after watching hours of antifa videos on YouTube. Tuck has pled not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.

"Jackson, whose social media pages say he's a 100% disabled Marine, surrendered to the FBI on May 18: The FBI stated in court documents that he posted photos on social media of himself on Jan. 6 in a plaid shirt and other clothing he wore to the riot, photos agents later used to identify him. He was dubbed #TartanPlaidPB by online sleuths who are researching those who participated in the Capitol riot, then turning that information over to the FBI. Jackson is seen in photos numerous times on Jan. 6 with Proud Boys from Arizona, and wore one of their orange arm bands, the FBI stated. However, in an interview with the FBI at his home, agents said Jackson told them he is not affiliated with the Proud Boys and doesn't support their ideology. He said they gave him the orange band and he stayed with them for protection because he had traveled to Washington, D.C. alone. However, the FBI noted that in December, one of his social media connections tagged him in a post about a group of Proud Boys being in New York City. In a social media post included in the court records, Jackson said he didn't agree with the "MAGA tribalism," and didn't commit any violence. Jackson stated in the post that he had evidence of BLM, Antifa, police officers and "Non Trump" extremists "causing the mayhem." Jackson also stated that he's a college student studying to be a political science professor. "My only love is the United States of America," he wrote. At the Capitol, records show he carried a U.S. flag and was with a crowd singing The Star-Spangled Banner after the detonation of an explosive device in the crowd. He then pointed toward the Senate Wing of the Capitol and moved that direction. The agents noted he was seen on video in Statuary Hall and other locations inside the Capitol." (USA Today)

Daniel Lyons "Milkshake" Scott, 28 of Florida, pled guilty to obstruction of justice/Congress and assault on a federal officer with physical contact and intent to commit another felony for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 60 months of incarceration. He self-identifies as a Proud Boy member and wore a black ballistic vest, goggles, and a carabiner on his vest into the Capitol. He "has a tattoo of the organization on his left arm, according to the FBI. In a Wall Street Journal video from Jan. 6, Scott is seen walking alongside known members of the Proud Boys in Washington, D.C. On the same video, a man is heard screaming: “Let’s take the f***ing Capitol.” Another individual then answers: “Let’s not f***ing yell that, all right?” Ethan Nordean, one of the most powerful leaders in the organization, then responds: “It was Milkshake, man, you know … idiot.” Later at the Capitol, additional footage from various sources shows Scott pushing two police officers backward up the steps. Scott appears to be one of the first people to initiate contact with law enforcement and is seen later pulling officers into the crowd." (NPR)

"On March 24, 2022, Nathan A. Bergstrom, a 42-year-old resident of Arizona, was sentenced in the Western District of Kentucky to time served after pleading guilty to unlawful possession of a firearm. According to court records, Bergstrom is a “self proclaimed Boogaloo Boi” who was initially arrested at a Greyhound Bus Station in Phoenix, Arizona in January 2021. Bergstrom’s initial arrest was based on probable cause that he committed felony misconduct involving weapons, in violation of Arizona criminal code. After being released, Bergstrom failed to appear for his preliminary hearing, and a bench warrant was subsequently issued for his arrest. On March 13, 2021, Bergstrom was identified by the FBI as a participant in an event in Louisville, Kentucky, which was attended by multiple adherents of the Boogaloo movement. During the event, Bergstrom was arrested by law enforcement, who discovered a handgun on his person. A search warrant for Bergstrom’s cell phone also revealed screen shots of a pair of Greyhound bus tickets from New Mexico to Ohio, purchased under aliases, in an attempt to conceal Bergstrom’s identity and flee Arizona to avoid prosecution."

On October 3, 2020, members of The Base, a white supremacist group, broke into unoccpied Michigan Dept. of Corrections buildings in Caro, Michigan. The men, Thomas Denton, Justen Watkins, and Tristan Webb stole government owned clothing and allegedly broke into the gauge the potential of the buildings for use as "hate camps" or training grounds. All were charged with larceny of a building, gang membership, conspiracy to commit teaching use of firearms for a civil disorder, and felony firearm.

"David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an American flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26." (NPR)

On February 5, 2021, in Washington D.C., Nathaniel J. DeGrave, age 31, of Las Vegas, Nevada, was charged with assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building, and acts of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings. DeGrave entered the Capitol building during the January 6 riot and shoved a Capitol police officer while inside. His actions were motivated by his rightist: anti-government beliefs.

In 2021, in Washington D.C., Ronald Lawrence Sandlin, 31, of Las Vegas, Nevada, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building following his particpation in the Capitol riot. Sandlin was identified via numerous photographs taken inside the Capitol and was filmed smoking marijuana in the rotunda of the Capitol building.

Joshua Dillion Haynes, 39 of Virginia, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction. He was sentenced to 32 months in prison for his role in the Capitol Raid. He was recorded on video attacking members of the media at a staging area near the Capitol, crushing their equipment and stealing their camera. According to local news reporting, Haynes was angry specifically at CNN. "Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."" (NPR)

James Russell Davis, 45, of King George, VA, a former Marine and self-proclaimed Proud Boy, is charged with crimes related to his participation in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. He charged at police officers with a large stick.

Riley June Williams, 22 of Pennsylvania, was found guilty of civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding law enforcement officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building for her role in the Capitol raid. She was sentenced to 36 months of prison. Williams is alleged to have stolen the laptop of Speak of the House Nancy Pelosi, though an aid to the speaker said it was a laptop used only for presentations. Video from the incident shows her directing other rioters upstairs. According to her mother whom she lives with, Williams, "had taken a sudden interest in President Donald Trump’s politics and 'far-right message boards.'" (AP)

Steven Thurlow, 50 of Michigan, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid."A witness contacted the FBI identifying Steven Thurlow as having been inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, according to court documents. "The witness also provided screenshots of Thurlow’s Facebook posts, including one in which he is seen wearing camouflage tactical gear with a “Boogaloo” patch on his chest. The extremist Boogaloo movement anticipates a second civil war in America, and some adherents even seek to bring about that conflict. “Ahh nothing like a new pair of 511’s and fresh set of level IV SAPI’s in the plate carrier to go “peacefully protest” with, the caption to the picture read, referring to a high-level ballistic body armor plate, Thurlow had allegedly purchased. According to the FBI, Thurlow served in the Army from 1988 until 1991. A second witness told the FBI that Thurlow had become something of a “conspiracy theorist” after joining the military. Inside the Capitol building, photos show Thurlow lying on what appears to be a conference room table. He is also seen walking around the hallways recording on his cellphone, wearing a camouflage jacket, a yellow scarf and white rimmed sunglasses.""(NPR) He served in the US Army 101st Airborne 1988-1991, served abroad in Saudia Arabia for 6 months in 1990.

Anthony Sargent is charged with engaging in physical violence, destruction of property and various acts of illegal entry and disorderly conduct. He was identified through the FBI BOLO list because of his knuckle tattoos. He can be seen in surveilance photos throwing what looks like a brick at the windows of the Capitol building. His social media shows a connection to the Proud Boys.

"Gilbert Fonticoba was arrested on Oct. 26 in Miami and charged in a felony indictment with six counts, including obstructing an official proceeding and civil disorder. He must appear at an arraignment in District Court in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 2. According to his LinkedIn page and multiple news outlets, Fonticoba has appeared at rallies for Trump in Florida and supports the Proud Boys." (NPR)

In the days leading up to January 6, 2021, Edward Thomas Spain, Jr, 55, posted messages on right-wing media site Parler warning that civil war was imminent and that Joe Biden's electoral college victory was a sign of America being a "banana republic." Then, on January 6, Spain  was found to have illegally entered the U.S. Capitol building with the mob in Washington D.C. He took photos of himself at the event and posted them to social media; the posts were then found by the FBI, who connected the posts to a phone number belonging to Spain and to usage of a cell site servicing the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question. Spain was later interviewed at his Oklahoma home, where he confirmed his presence at the riot and his entrance into the United States Capitol. Spain was then charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot.
veteranStatus: Former active duty and reserve components

event: Footage of the livestream filmed within the U.S. Capitol on January 6 by Anthime Gionet showed Daniel Goodwyn, 32, who was called out as "sfthoughtcriminal," within the building during the violent events that took place that day. Goodwyn stated his full, correct name into the camera and was shown confronting officers that told him to leave by calling them "oathbreakers." An associate of Goodwyn conversed with him over Instagram regarding his participation in the riot and recorded a post to Goodwyn's account stating that he entered the Capitol without causing any damage; screenshots of both, turned over to the FBI, were what alerted them to Goodwyn in the first place. Goodwyn is a member of the politically-violent extremist group known as the Proud Boys, which was known to be prevalent and active in the siege of the U.S. Capitol on January 6th. In the months leading up to it, Goodwyn made several declarations over social media that signaled his affiliation with them as well as his support for the objections to the results of the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election that catalyzed the gathering of protesters at the U.S. Capitol that day. After this information was collected, Goodwyn was arrested and charged.

When a Proud Boys’ leader asked the crowd, “Do you want your house back?” on Jan. 6, 2021, near the U.S. Capitol, video footage allegedly shows Lisa Anne Homer standing next to him yelling, “Yes!” and then "taunting" police at the front of the protest lines, according to an FBI statement of facts. Homer added a camouflage helmet and googles to her tactical vest before entering the Capitol, where subpoenaed phone records indicate she remained for over an hour. Homer has posted a Proud Boys emblem to her social media, as well as photos taken at the Proud Boys’ Million MAGA March in Washington, D.C., in November 2020, according to the statement of facts. She was arrested on Nov. 26, 2021, in Colorado Springs, Colo. (NPR)

Federal prosecutors allege that Ronald Loehrke took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named James Haffner. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Loehrke and Haffner marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building. When a line of police protecting the outside of the Capitol stopped people from advancing farther, Loehrke allegedly said, "Don't back down, patriots! The whole f****** world is watching. Stand the f*** up today!" At one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Ronald Loehrke was arrested in Cumming, Ga., on Dec. 3, 2021. (NPR)

On March 23rd, 2021, Jonathanpeter Klein and his brother Matthew Leland Klein, both self-proclaimed members of the Proud Boys, were indicted on charges of 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges, and their sentencing is pending. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
