"Prosecutors allege that at least two people called the FBI to report that Timothy Earl O'Malley had been at the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol and that one of those tipsters said O'Malley has previously identified himself as a Proud Boy. In an interview with the FBI, O'Malley said that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Florida to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to court documents, O'Malley wore a red softball batting helmet with a "Trump is my president" bumper sticker on the side, because he said he had heard that antifa followers had sacks of rocks they were planning to throw. In his interview, O'Malley described the scene at the Capitol as "mayhem" and admitted to entering the building, where he can allegedly also be seen on security camera footage. The FBI also obtained videos from O'Malley's cellphone through a warrant. In one video, O'Malley allegedly yells, "WE FOUGHT OUR WAY, ALL THE WAY IN THERE. AND WE FOUGHT OUR WAY BACK OUT ... WE SWARMED THE CAPITOL, THOUGH. HOT DAMN."" (NPR)

Ricky Christopher Willden, 39, a resident of California was arrested for his involvement in the January 6th Captial Riots. "Publicly available videos show Ricky Christopher Willden cheering at the Capitol building on Jan. 6 near the east door around 2:30 in the afternoon, wearing a dark jacket, beanie cap and gloves, according to court documents. About10 minutes later, he can be seen raising his hand and spraying an unknown substance from a green can toward police officers standing guard. According to the FBI, Willden is a self-proclaimed member of the far right-extremist group The Proud Boys, whose members describe themselves as "Western Chauvinists."" (NPR)

Court documents indicate that Freedom Vy was identified as a person involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after law enforcement obtained and searched the phone records of Zachary Rehl, who is also charged and is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Vy is charged with Brian Healion and Isaiah Giddings, who were all allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person who was not in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The group members coordinated their travel from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021, according to court records. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument. They both flashed the "OK" hand sign, which is associated with the Proud Boys, according to court documents. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, and appear there in photos and videos. (NPR)

Law enforcement allegedly identified Isaiah Giddings as a person who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after searching the phone records of another person charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Giddings is charged with two other men, Brian Healion and Freedom Vy, who were allegedly part of a Telegram message group with Rehl and another person who was not in Washington, D.C., on the day of the insurrection. The group coordinated travel from Philadelphia to D.C. ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on the night before the riot, according to court records. On the day of the riot, Giddings allegedly appeared in a photograph outside the U.S. Capitol with Rehl and others, all flashing the "OK" hand symbol, a gesture associated with the Proud Boys. The four men then allegedly entered the Capitol building, where the four of them appear in several photos and videos. In a reply to a text the next day asking how they were doing, Giddings allegedly wrote: “Yes we have everything and everyone all accounted for ... none of our Philly guys had any PB gear the entire event just plain trump supporters from beginning to end." According to news reports, the Proud Boys were directed not to wear their signature black and yellow on the day of the riot, aiming to blend in with other Trump supporters. (NPR)

In January 2022, Daniel James Anderson (26) of Kennewick, Washington, and Connor Duane Goodman of Auburn, Washington, were indicted on criminal charges after allegedly conspiring to build explosives to be used against law enforcement personnel. The charges include conspiracy to make or possess an unregistered destructive device and possession of an unregistered destructive device, as well as allegations of forfeiture. Goodman and Kennewick are members of a self-described anti-authority group known as the Verified Bois. The Verified Bois reportedly share the same beliefs associated with the “boogaloo” movement. Anderson was arrested and taken into custody in December 2021. It is not known if or when Goodman was arrested. No pleas have been entered at this time.

Shortly after the election in November 2020, prosecutors say, Rhodes and others began planning travel to Washingto D.C. and training for action there. As the crowd gathered outside the U.S. Capitol on 1/6/2021, about 2 p.m., federal prosecutors say Rhodes entered the restricted area of the Capitol grounds and directed his followers to meet him at the Capitol. Court records say two groups of Oath Keepers, many in paramilitary clothing bearing Oath Keepers patches and insignia, then formed military-style "stack" formations and invaded the Capitol.

"Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Ulrich conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6. Ulrich has been indicted along with several members of the group. According to the indictment, Ulrich goes by the moniker "Molon Labe" and allegedly participated in conversations on the encrypted messaging service Signal in a group message labeled "DC OP: Jan 6 21." On Dec. 31, Ulrich reportedly wrote the following message on the chat: "The more patriots the merrier 'gonna be wild." Later he allegedly wrote, "Someone can tell me if I'm crazy but I'm planning on having a backpack for regular use and then a separate backpack with my ammo load out with some basics that I can [just] switch too is [sic] s**t truly the fan blades. ..." According to court documents, Ulrich also asked another member on Signal: "Hey we told to bring guns and maybe stage them in VA ...?" On Jan. 4. Ulrich traveled with others to Washington, D.C., from Alabama and Georgia, and stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, court documents say. On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He continued on foot and ultimately pushed his way inside through the Rotunda doors, and then, according to court documents, left the same way he came in." (NPR)

Robert Gieswein, 24, of Woodland Park, CO was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous easpon [3 counts]; Destruction of Government property; and Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot. Gieswein was identified via footage taken at the riot and can be clearly seen illegally entering the US capitol in paramilitary gear carrying a baseball bat and weilding an unidentified spray bottle which he used to spray at Capitol police officers. Gieswein appears to be affiliated with the domestic group the Three Percenters which is related to the Oath Keepers. Additionally, Gieswein runs a private paramilitary group in Colorado called the Woodland Wild Dogs. In an interview, Gieswein offers up anti-semitic conspiracy theories as part of his reasoning for his actions.
groupAffiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Woodland Wild Dogs
affiliations: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Woodland Wild Dogs

event: On January 28, 2022, Matthew Edward Chen was arrrested in Pomona, CA on for selling silencers to undercover FBI agents. He is a self-declared member of the Boogaloo Bois movement, specificially the Cali Bois. Chen uses the alias "Dolphin" in Cali Bois circles, and was also recorded giving a presentation over silencers and how to obtain them privately. His order of detention states that he may suffer from mental illness and is considered a flight risk because of his dual citizenship (other country unnamed).

On February 23, 2022, Christopher Brenner Cook, Jonathan Allen Frost, and Jackson Matthew Sawall pled guilty to charges relating to their plot to provide material support to a terrorist organization. The group in this case was a neo-nazi organization that intended to use the weapons, explosives, and other materials gathered to attack a number of energy substations in Ohio. The aim for this group was to instigate social unrest and use that to exploit existing racial tensions to promote white supremacist and white nationalist ideals.

According to an affidavit and criminal complaint, Alan Fischer III marched to the Capitol on 1/6/2022 with members of the Proud Boys. Once there, he moved to the vicinity of the terrace on the west side of the Capitol, where he joined others in pushing against law enforcement at the arched entrance to a passageway into the building. The group of rioters collectively pushed against officers, at times rocking together in a coordinated way, to gain entry to the interior of the building. He remained in this area for a period of more than 45 minutes. Later, according to the court documents, Fischer moved to the west front of the Capitol. Once there, he threw chairs, an orange traffic cone, and a pole towards officers.

"Wearing a black beanie stitched with a yellow wreath commonly associated with the Proud Boys and a white cowboy hat that referenced the Stop the Steal slogan, Joshua John Portlock allegedly shrugged when officers ordered him out of a tunnel into the U.S. Capitol building. In reply, Portlock allegedly gestured to the crowd surrounding him and said “I can’t with this." He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3 in Smyrna, Tenn." (NPR)

Rachel Myers, a 30-year-old who works at Delilah’s Gentlemen’s Club in Philadelphia, was charged along with Michael Gianos, who traveled to Washington with her for the Jan. 6 insurrection, the FBI says. According to the warrant, Myers stayed in a hotel with a man named Lawrence Stackhouse, of Blackwood, N.J. Stackhouse was arrested in March after several tips from coworkers who said it was “common knowledge” he was at the Capitol and had called out of work Jan. 5 and 6 to attend. In the days after the election of President Joe Biden, Myers and Gianos texted each other expressing the belief that the election had been stolen from Donald Trump and planning a trip to Washington to stop the certification process.

Steven Miles and Matthew LeBrun were both arrested and charged on April 7, 2022 for their actions during the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol. Steven Miles could be seen through numerous cctv and cell-phone videos along the West Terrace riot line both with and without LeBrun. The pair could later be seen smashing and breaching a window near the Senate Carriage Door before wandering the halls of the Senate Wing. Miles had also been observed in cell phone and body-camera footage shoving and hitting a Capitol Police officer

Steven Miles and Matthew LeBrun were both arrested and charged on April 7, 2022 for their actions during the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol.LeBrun could be seen around the West Terrace in multiple CCTC and cell phone videos from the day, before joining Miles to smash a window in the Senate Wing and enter the building. LeBrun could be seen wearing a tactical vest with a patch featuring the logo for the III% Militia group

On November 19, 2021, Eric Anthony Rome called the South Carolina Department of Corrections from prison in Columbia, SC and stated that he, with the support of the Aryan Brotherhood and the Proud Boys, would wage war on the federal government. He also stated that they intended to assassinate "the feds, Marxist leaders Joe Biden and Kamala Harris". He referred to a stolen election and the vax mandate as his reason(s), then continued on and threatened several judges.

Jerry Ryals was charged with 18 U.S.C. § 231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol insurrection Ryals plead guilty on 5/5/22 to the count of Civil Disorder (following a superseding information) and sentencing information is pending. ""We reclaimed our Capitol, just to be slandered by the media," Ryals wrote on Facebook after the riot, according to the FBI. "Things are headed in the direction of a Revolutionary war against the corruption of our government. "It is our responsibility to handle this at all costs. We are not animals, we are not barbarians, we are the heart of this country and the last ones to stand up for your freedom." Ryals, an apprentice electrician, traveled to Washington D.C. with his boss, Anthony Griffith, to attend the President's rally. The FBI said both men admitted going inside the Capitol. Several witnesses identified Ryals and Griffith." (USA Today)

"William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean." (NPR)

Barry Bennet Ramey, 38, of Plantation, Florida was arrested and charged for his participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A member of the Proud Boys, Ramey came into conflict with U.S. Capitol Police officers on the west side of the building; he was part of the mob pushing against the officers attempting to stop them from climbing the stairwell from the Lower West Terrace to the Upper West Terrace. It is here that Ramey sprayed officers in the eyes with an orange chemical agent, causing disorientation and pain. Though video footage of the incident was captured, the officers were not able to identify the perpetrator of the attack due to the impairment of their vision at the time. Ramey was identified using cell phone location data provided by AT&T--which showed that the phone belonging to Ramey had been using the cell site servicing the U.S. Capitol Building, testimony from the manager of Hilton Arlington Hotel, and identification from a former neighbor. Ramey was then arrested on charges of assaulting police, engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building and civil disorder.

"Federal prosecutors allege that, in the days after the 2020 election, Rodney Milstreed messaged a friend on Facebook warning that things could get "ugly" in the country, along with a photo of multiple military-style rifles, ammunition and a medical kit. On Nov. 25, 2020, court documents state, he posted on Facebook, "I pray every night. I hope we dont have to hurt anyone. THESE JUDGES BETTER DO THE RIGHT THING." On Jan. 6, 2021, Milstreed allegedly threw a flagpole "javelin-style" at a group of Capitol Police officers guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol. Brandon Clint Russell (aka Homunculus & Raccoon), 27, and Sarah Beth Clendaniel (aka Nythra88 & Kali1889), 34, are accused of conspiring to destroy energy facilities in the area of Baltimore, Maryland and Delaware. The substations were located in Norrisville, Reisterstown and Perry Hall, MD, and the final 2 in Baltimore City. They had previously mentioned targeting a substation in Delaware, just beyond the MD border, as well. According to prosecutors, the plans was to damage 5 electrical substations in the Baltimore area with gunfire or through the use of Mylar balloons to cause an electrical short. Then defendants talked about destroying a "ring" around the city, leading to 'complete destruction' of the city through 'cascading failures'--timing the attacks when the electrical grid was already strained (i.e., hot summer or cold winter). The couple were both unknowingly speaking to federal informants in prison during their conspiracy, leading to their arrest. Although the plans began in prison, they continued after Russell was released on parole August 2021, and a focus on the infrastructure attacks began June 2022. The couple met while both were incarcerated in separate facilities--Russell was incarcerated for possessing bomb making materials as part of the Atomwaffen Division, and Clendaniel was imprisoned for robbery. Clendaniel told the informant the she expected to die of kidney disease within months and wanted the attacks to leave a statement. Investigators located a document, described as resembling a manifesto, which includes references to Ted Kaczynski, Anders Brevic and Adolf Hitler. The two reportedly were in contact from 2018 until their arrests in February 2023. Russell is a former Florida National Guard member and a founder of Atomwaffen, and Russell lived with Devon Arthurs, another Atomwaffen member arrested in 2017 for murder, but who had similarly planted to attack US electrical sites and nuclear power plants.

"The FBI alleges that images from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show William Hendry Mellors firing a canister of bear spray toward police officers on a staircase leading into the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. “Took a nice beat down from Washington DC police tonight. Some tear gas and a riot baton. Broken ribs and some stitches needed,” Mellors later wrote on Parler as a caption for a close-up photo of what appears to be his own bloody ear, according to an FBI statement of facts. Mellors told FBI agents in April 2022 that he’d joined some “rabid” protesters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, also mentioning that a group of Proud Boys had asked him to “walk some ladies back to their hotel to protect them from Antifa” during the Trump rally in November 2020. He added that the Proud Boys “seemed like nice people.” When FBI agents interviewed Mellors a second time in May, he said he expected to be arrested and confirmed he brought two canisters of bear spray to Washington. He was arrested on July 18, 2022, in Houston" NPR

On June 13, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Richard Zachary Ackerman, 22, of Salem, NH for theft of government property, obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder, resisting a person engaged in official duties, entering and remaining on restricted grounds, and disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted grounds. On January 6, 2021, Ackerman was part of the crowd that attempted to break a police barricade in the Lower West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. "Nathan Weeden, 23, of Houghton, Michigan [was indicted] for conspiring with others and allegedly defacing Temple Jacob – a Jewish synagogue in Hancock, Michigan – with swastikas and symbols associated with The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist group...Weeden, along with other public documents filed in cases against alleged co-conspirators Richard Tobin of New Jersey and Yousef Barasneh of Wisconsin, support the following allegations. According to the indictment, in September 2019, Weeden, Tobin, and Barasneh – all members of The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist organization – allegedly used an encrypted messaging platform to discuss vandalizing property associated with African Americans and Jewish Americans. Weeden and his co-conspirators dubbed their plan, “Operation Kristallnacht,” which in German means “Night of Broken Glass” and is in reference to the events that took place on November 9th and 10th of 1938 in which Nazis murdered Jewish people and burned and destroyed their homes, synagogues, schools, and places of business. The indictment alleges that Weeden carried out this plan on September 21, 2019, when he spray-painted swastikas and symbols associated with The Base on the outside walls of Temple Jacob. Weeden is charged with two counts. The first count is for Conspiracy Against Rights under 18 U.S.C. § 241, a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to conspire to injure, oppress, threaten, or intimidate any person in the exercise of their rights...The second count is for Damage to Religious Property under 18 U.S.C. § 247, also a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to intentionally deface, damage, or destroy religious property because of the race or ethnic characteristics of individuals associated with that religious property. The maximum penalty under this statute is 1 year imprisonment and a $100,000 fine...The grand jury issued its two-count indictment against Nathan Weeden on June 27, 2023. The indictment was unsealed on June 29, 2023, after the defendant was arrested by the FBI. He remains in custody at this time. The court will schedule Weeden’s arraignment, detention hearing, and trial at a later date." (DOJ)
